items.title: Crossing over to Lofoten
items.summary: We are lucky to be allowed onto the 4 pm…
items.content_html:
We are lucky to be allowed onto the 4 pm ferry even though our booking is for the last one which leaves Bodo at 6.45 pm. Which means we reach our destination 2 hours ahead of schedule. The weather couldn't be better, sunny and warm. The views back to the main land as well as to the Lofoten further into the crossing are breathtaking. The crossing itself is getting a bit choppy the further out into the Atlantic we are getting.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Day 4 on the road
items.summary: Today I am crossing the Arctic Circle. It's another brilliant…
items.content_html:
Today I am crossing the Arctic Circle. It's another brilliant driving day. Only 250 km to Bodo Airport, but what stunning scenery! Medha's flight is on time, and by 3 pm my lonely days are officially over. 

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: An evening hike(let)
items.summary: After a 10 hour drive it's time to stretch those…
items.content_html:
After a 10 hour drive it's time to stretch those legs. The owner of the little hut I am staying in overnight (overlooking one of Norway's zillions of fjords) points me to a path right by the cabin, and up I hike. It's not as convenient as hiking in the German Alps as there is quite a bit of undergrowth to juggle with, but in about half an hour I come to a little clearing with some nice views. As it is already getting late, I sensibly decide to turn around making this a short but nice little change to my driving routine.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Day 3 on the road
items.summary: It's the longest driving day yet. Almost 10 hours for…
items.content_html:
It's the longest driving day yet. Almost 10 hours for about 650 km including one ferry crossing. The scenery is suddenly very different the further up North I am getting. It reminds me of Finland or Sweden with loads of trees and lakes. This will be my last day of solitude as Medha will be arriving tomorrow in Bodo by plane. Then our Lofoten adventure can begin.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Atlantic Ocean Road
items.summary: I thought the Atlantic Ocean Road deserves its own post.
items.content_html:
I thought the Atlantic Ocean Road deserves its own post. Not because I have to drive it twice thanks to Mr. TomTom, once from East to West, then back from West to East to get back to my accomodation in Sveggvika. But because it really is a stunning piece of road, indeed. Being only a mere 8 km long and made up of 8 bridges, it claims to be one of the most scenic drives in the world, hugging the Atlantic coast, at some places right on the edge. The construction of the road started in August 1983 and it took six years to finish it. So it's not surprising that it is usually packed out with tourists. I am quite lucky today, not only because the weather is a bit moody but also because the main tourist season is coming to an end. One thing is certain: under no circumstances would I ever want to come here in July or early August when everyone is flogging this stretch of road. 

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Day 2 on the road
items.summary: Nothing is stopping me from getting an early start as…
items.content_html:
Nothing is stopping me from getting an early start as I wake up at 3.30 am. As breakfast in my hotel doesn't start before 7.30 am, however, it's finally after 8.00 am when I am heading off into what I believe will turn out to be a very wet day. Miracles can happen, it turns out, and as time moves on so does the rain move away. Not completely, but enough to be able to get out of the car every now and then without being completely drenched. Today's leg is a mere 220 km to which I end up adding another 60 as I make the mistake of not checking which route my TomTom has in store for me. Too late do I realize it's having a mind of its own taking me to my overnight stop from the East, whereas I had wanted to come in from the West via the Atlantic Ocean Road.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Day 1 on the road
items.summary: A brilliant first driving day. The weather isn't as bad…
items.content_html:
A brilliant first driving day. The weather isn't as bad as I feared after waking up to pouring rain. The atmosphere changes quickly from bright and sunny to dark and moody. Great for taking pictures. The going is quite slow with speed limits often at 60 km, never more than 80 km. Fortunately, the main tourist season is over and there are only very few cars on the roads, and most of them are travelling South and not like me up North. The most interesting part of the trip are the frequent tunnels, sometimes up to 5 km long. Nothing for the claustrophobic ones, they tend to be rather narrow and dark. I reach my first destination Grotli after about 360 km and a total driving time of about 6 hours. Winding down in the cozy Hotel bar with a nice Norwegian Gin & Tonic.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Through the Water Maze
items.summary: The last stretch from Stavangar to Bergen is quite dramatic…
items.content_html:
The last stretch from Stavangar to Bergen is quite dramatic as the ferry takes a route through what I would describe as a "Water Maze" passing by little islands and stretches of coastline that are connected by yet more ferries. A truly amazing scenery. Even more so as it has stopped raining cats and dogs and changed into a mixture of clouds and sunny spells.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: The Crossing
items.summary: Ferry leaves before departure time. That must be Scandinavian efficiency.
items.content_html:
Ferry leaves before departure time. That must be Scandinavian efficiency. My cabin is cozy, the bed comfy and the crossing surprisingly calm and not rocky. Waking up at 6 am when we reach our first stop Stavangar. It's still dark outside but I can sense the rain. Which proves to be true when I next wake up two hours later. Good morning Norway. And a big smiley hello to wet weather.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Denmark
items.summary: After a short night with barely 5 hours of sleep…
items.content_html:
After a short night with barely 5 hours of sleep (is it apprehension that prevents me from drifting off?), it's "get up and get going" onto the second leg of my journey. The 630 km to the North of Denmark are pretty boring driving through mostly very flat countryside. Despite losing about an hour near Hamburg in a traffic jam, I am at my destination 3 hours early. Which means more boredom waiting for the Fjordline check-in counters to open.
